block.p: Apple Warns on Earnings, And Stock Falls After Hours Apple Computer said that its fourth-quarter earnings would fall far below estimates because of weak September sales. Earnings will be 30 cents to 33 cents a share in the quarter, below analysts' forecasts of 45 cents.
Shares of Apple, which had closed at $53.50, up $4.56, dropped as low as $28.25 in after-hours trading. [Page C2.]

Denmark Decides Not to Adopt Euro Denmark voted not to join Europe's unified currency, the euro, undermining a fragile monetary experiment and turning its back on the rapid European political integration championed by France and Germany. Results showed 53.1 percent voting against the euro and 46.9 percent in favor. In New York, the euro settled at 88.13 cents, down from 88.30. [A1.]

P.& G. Leads Rebound in Stocks Reassuring comments by Procter & Gamble helped lift stocks. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 195.70 points, or 1.8 percent, to 10,824.06. The Nasdaq composite index gained 122.02 points, or 3.3 percent, to 3,778.32. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 31.72 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,458.29. [C8.]
Firestone Faces Reshuffling at Top Bridgestone/Firestone, which is recalling 6.5 million tires, is also facing growing uncertainty about who will run the company. [C6.]

Business Dean Is Stepping Down Donald P. Jacobs, one of the most influential people in management education, will step down next spring after a quarter-century as the dean of Northwestern University's business school. Mr. Jacobs, 73, has served longer than any current major university president or other business school dean, higher education experts said. [C9.]
Delays for Sony's Playstation 2 Sony confirmed that it would fall far short of having a million Playstation 2 devices ready for sale on Oct. 26. [C7.]
